questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following functions are likely to be impaired in patients with peripheral 
neuropathy?
questions.explanation:
Peripheral neuropathies can impair sensory, motor, or autonomic function, either singly or in 
combination. Peripheral nerves are composed of sensory, motor, and autonomic elements. Peripheral neuropathies are classified into those that primarily affect the • Cell body - neuronopathy or ganglionopathy • Myelin - myelinopathy • Axon - axonopathy

questions.question: Question 2: Disorders of autonomic function should be considered in patients with:
questions.explanation: Disorders of autonomic function (dysautonomia) is usually considered in patients with: • Unexplained orthostatic hypotension (OH) • Syncope • Sleep dysfunction • Altered sweating (hyperhidrosis or hypohidrosis) • Impotence • Constipation or other GI symptoms like bloating, nausea, vomiting of old food, diarrhea. • Bladder disorders such as urinary frequency, hesitancy, or incontinence.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 50-year-old woman complains of numbness of her hands, generalized weakness, and easy 
fatiguability. She is a vegetarian. She looks very pale and her peripheral smear reveals 
macrocytic hypochromic anemia. If untreated, she is at risk of developing which of the 
following conditions?
questions.explanation:
1137 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario of macrocytic anemia and a vegetarian diet is suggestive of vitamin B12 
deficiency. This typically leads to large fiber neuropathy which presents with loss of 
proprioception and vibration. Smaller-diameter myelinated and unmyelinated fibers transmit pain and temperature sensation. 
Hence, small fiber neuropathies present as temperature loss or burning or stabbing pain.

questions.question:
Question 4: Small fiber neuropathies can be seen in patients with all of the following conditions, except: 1132 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Sjogren’s syndrome does not cause small fiber neuropathy. It causes preferential large fiber 
sensory neuropathy.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 30-year-old man presents with weakness of both the lower limbs. On examination, there is 
a sensory loss in the lower limbs and both the proximal and distal leg muscles have reduced 
power. This presentation is characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario suggests symmetric proximal and distal weakness with sensory loss. 
This pattern is characteristic of acquired immune demyelinating polyneuropathies. It consists of: • Acute form - Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy [AIDP] also known 
as Guillain-Barré syndrome [GBS] • Chronic form - Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy [CIDP] Option B: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a multiple degenerative motor neuron disease. It 
leads to muscle weakness and disability in the absence of sensory symptoms and signs. Option C: Mononeuropathy multiplex refers to multiple compressive mononeuropathies. It 
presents as asymmetric subacute or acute sensory and motor symptoms and signs. Option D: Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus presents with asymmetric 
weakness.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient presented with peripheral neuropathy with asymmetric distal weakness without 
sensory loss. The differential diagnosis for this condition would include all except:
questions.explanation:
Hereditary motor neuropathy does not present with asymmetric distal weakness without sensory 
loss. It presents with symmetric distal weakness without sensory loss.

questions.question: Question 7: What is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy?
questions.explanation:
Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. Other examples of rare hereditary neuropathies are Friedreich’s ataxia, familial amyloid 
polyneuropathy and Tangier disease. 1138 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: 1133 
Sold by @itachibot All of the following are associated with autonomic neuropathies, except:
questions.explanation:
In hyperthyroidism, excessive thyroxine causes sympathetic autonomic overactivity, not 
neuropathy. Hypothyroidism can be associated with peripheral neuropathy, most typically carpal tunnel 
syndrome. Treatment is the correction of hypothyroidism.

questions.question:
Question 9: A young woman presents with complaints of insomnia due to her feet becoming very hot and 
painful at night. On examination, she has multiple superficial foot ulcers, and she is unable to 
feel light touch and crude touch. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of burning feet syndrome, seen in HSAN 1. There are five types of hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathies (HSAN I–V), of which 
the most important are HSAN I and HSAN III. HSAN I has an autosomal dominant inheritance. It presents in adolescence or adulthood as a 
distal small-fiber neuropathy. It causes burning feet syndrome in which patients present with: • Burning sensation of feet, especially at night • Sensory loss • Foot ulcers. Option B: Dejerine Roussy syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome usually occurs after 
a stroke. The patient experiences burning pain over affected areas of the body. Option C: HSAN III or Riley Day syndrome presents in childhood. It presents with labile BP, 
decreased tearing, hyperhidrosis, reduced sensitivity to pain, and areflexia. Option D: Charcot Marie Tooth disease is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. It is a 
hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN) which presents with motor weakness and 
skeletal deformities.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is the most common type of neuropathy seen in diabetes?

options.d: Distal Symmetric Sensory and Sensorimotor Polyneuropathy

questions.explanation:
Distal symmetric sensory and sensorimotor polyneuropathy (DSPN) is the most common form of 
diabetic neuropathy and is seen in approximately one-third of patients with DM. Other neuropathies seen in diabetes mellitus are: • The most common mononeuropathies are median neuropathy at the wrist and ulnar neuropathy 
at the elbow • Diabetic autonomic neuropathy is typically seen in combination with DSPN • Cranial neuropathy (third nerve palsy is the most common) and diabetic neuropathic cachexia The Michigan diabetic neuropathy score is a screening tool used to assess diabetic neuropathy.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following can be prescribed as a first-line drug for a patient with painful diabetic 
neuropathy?
questions.explanation:
1139 
Sold by @itachibot Duloxetine is a selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the 
first-line drugs used in the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies: • First-line: • Lidoderm 5% patch • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline) • Gabapentin, Pregabalin • Duloxetine • Second-line: • Carbamazepine • Phenytoin • Venlafaxine • Tramadol • Third-line: • Mexiletine Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its 
complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral 
neuropathy.

questions.question: Question 12: Sensorimotor neuropathy may be caused by all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Lead poisoning does not cause sensorimotor neuropathy. It causes symptoms and signs of 
primarily motor neuropathy. The most common presentation of lead poisoning is encephalopathy. The sensation is generally preserved but the autonomic nervous system can be affected in lead 
poisoning.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following vitamins will you prescribe for a patient on antitubercular therapy?
questions.explanation:
Isoniazid (INH), which is a first-line anti-tuberculosis drug, inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase, 
resulting in pyridoxine deficiency and neuropathy. Prophylactic administration of vitamin B6 
(pyridoxine) 10 mg/day can prevent neuropathy from developing. 10 mg daily suffices for prophylaxis but patients with evidence of vitamin B6 deficiency may 
require up to 50 mg daily. Current WHO guidelines recommend routine substitution of pyridoxine to patients who are at 
risk of peripheral neuropathy, e.g., malnutrition, chronic alcohol dependence, diabetics, HIV. However, pyridoxine excess (acute intoxication or long-term use of large doses) is also found to 
cause peripheral neuropathy. 1140 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: During a regular health checkup, you notice the following nail finding in a 64-year-old man. 
He lives near a smelting industry on the banks of a river. Which of the following conditions 
can be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The image shows Mee’s lines, transverse white striae of the fingernails. This along with history 
is suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning probably due to a contaminated water source. Arsenic 
poisoning causes toxic sensorimotor polyneuropathy. The neuropathy manifests 5–10 days after ingestion of arsenic and progresses for several weeks, 
mimicking Guillain–Barre's Syndrome.

questions.question: Question 15: Identify the diagnosis.
questions.explanation:
The given image showing thickening of tissues in the temporal and orbital regions with coarse 
overlying skin suggests a diagnosis of plexiform neurofibroma. Plexiform neurofibroma represents an uncommon variant (30%) of neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1). 
Plexiform neurofibromas are usually evident at birth and result from a diffuse thickening of nerve 
trunks and surrounding tissues that are usually located in the orbital or temporal region of the 
face. The skin overlying it may be coarse and associated with hyperpigmentation. Plexiform neurofibromas may produce an overgrowth of an extremity and a deformity of the 
corresponding bone. NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present: • Six or more café-au-lait macules >5mm in prepubertal and >15mm in postpubertal • Axillary or inguinal freckling • Two or more iris lisch nodules • Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones with or 
without pseudoarthrosis. • Optic gliomas • A first-degree relative with NF-1 1141 
Sold by @itachibot Guillain-Barre Syndrome and Other Immune-mediated Neuropathies
